cootool.nature: Do you want to evaluate a generic group, like companies, communities, friends or a Cooperacy project one?
cootool.prevsurvey: Is there any previous survey ID you may want to refer to?
cootool.group: What kind of group do you want to evaluate?
cootool.country: Which is the country of your group?
cootool.place: Which is the place (i.e. the city in which you live, the company headquarters, the capital city for nations...) of your group?
cootool.newplace: If you do not find your place, please feel free to add a new
cootool.name: What is the name of your group?
cootool.member: What is the (approximate) number of your group participants?
cootool.desc: Please insert a description of the group and eventual current difficulties
cootool.groupcoointro: If you are evaluating yourself, 'the participants' are two: what you are now and what you would like to be. For the environment, please consider both the natural and physical space, like an office, a park or a house, where the participants actions take place.
cootool.MD: Do you consider yourself different than the other participants in your age, beliefs, language, wealth, culture and other characteristics?
cootool.D: Do you find the group participants are different one another? (Yes = all different, No = all similar)
cootool.MHD: Is the group environment different than your culture, values and beliefs?
cootool.HD: Is the group environment different than the participants culture, values and beliefs?
cootool.MU: Do you understand the other participants? (Yes = you understand everyone everytime, No = you never understand noone)
cootool.U: Do you find the group participants understand each other?
cootool.MHU: Do you know the group environment in detail and see it as familiar?
cootool.HU: Do the participants know the group environment in detail and see it as familiar? (Yes = everyone, No = noone)
cootool.MF: Do you feel free when you're within the group?
cootool.F: Do you think the participants feel free? (Yes = everyone, No = noone feels free.)
cootool.MHF: Do you feel free to move around in the group environment?
cootool.HF: Do the participants feel free to move around in the group environment? (Yes = everyone, No = noone)
cootool.MI: Do you feel you are free to show how you think and feel?
cootool.OI: Do you feel the other participants are free to show you how they think and feel?
cootool.I: Do the group participants feel free to show one another what they think or feel?
cootool.HI: Can the participants easily obtain informations about the group environment?
cootool.MHI: Can you easily obtain informations about the group environment?
cootool.MBC: Are you satisfied with money, goods or activities you receive from the group interaction?
cootool.MRC: Are you satisfied with the quality of emotions, relations, care and enjoyment of the group?
cootool.BC: Are the group participants satisfied with the money, goods, activities they receive from the group interaction?
cootool.RC: Are the group participants satisfied with the quality of emotions, relations, care and enjoyment of the group?
cootool.HC: Do the participants like the group environment?
cootool.MHC: Do you like the group environment?
cootool.MBT: Are the other participants reliable with you? Example: do they complete what they agree to do with you finishing it in a relative good time?
cootool.OBT: Are you reliable with the other participants? Example: do you complete what you agree to do with others finishing it in a relative good time?
cootool.MRT: Do other participants emotionally trust you? Example: can the other participants rely on you in terms of listening, affection, protection?
cootool.ORT: Do you emotionally trust the other participants? Example: can you rely on the other participants in terms of listening, affection, protection?
cootool.BT: Are the participants generally reliable one another? Example: do they complete what they agree to do finishing it on a relative good time?
cootool.RT: Do the participants emotionally trust each other? Example: can they rely one another in terms of listening, affection, protection?
cootool.MBXT: Do you expect money, goods, services or practical results from the group interaction will grow?
cootool.MRXT: Do you expect the quality of emotions, relations, care and enjoyment of the group will grow?
cootool.BXT: Do the participants expect money, goods, services or practical results from the group interaction will grow?
cootool.RXT: Do the participants expect the quality of emotions, relations, care and enjoyment of the group will grow?
cootool.HT: Do the participants feel the group environment is safe and reliable?
cootool.MHT: Do you feel the group environment is safe and reliable?
cootool.MBE: Think about the money, goods, services you receive compared to those of your peers. Are they similar? If not similar, are they proportional to your role and efforts?
cootool.MRE: Think about the quality of emotions, relations, care and enjoyment compared to those of your peers. Are they similar?
cootool.BE: Think about the money, goods, services the participants receive. Are they similar when compared? If not similar, are they proportional to the participants' roles and efforts?
cootool.RE: Think about the participants' quality of emotions, relations, care and enjoyment. Are they similar?
cootool.MHE: Think about the space dedicated to you. Are they similar compared to the other participants? If not similar, are they proportional to their roles and efforts?
cootool.HE: Think about the space dedicated to the particiapants. Are they similar? If not similar, are they proportional to their roles and efforts?
cootool.grouppairingintro:
PAIRING: READ BEFORE APPLYING
Use this part of the survey to pair your group, that is, to resolve internal conflicts.
You will also find final methodology advices.
cootool.grouppairingintro2:
The pairing tool is an innovative tool by Cooperacy that brings people to 'pair' their fundamental principles, in order to 'tune' the orientation of the human beliefs and then establish a methodology to take decisions.

The main question, 'how do we decide together', is the fundamental one. While the secret of self awareness held by gurus and spiritual masters in India leads to asking 'Who am I?', the secret of social coordination lies in the question 'How do we decide together?'
It is an invitation to establish a methodology about what to pratically do before taking a collective action in order to chose together. So the question isn't WHAT the group should do, but HOW the group decides what to do. Every group of people, even large 'social ecosystems', can decide its own. In our pairing tool, we propose a systematic way to do it, but just asking yourself and your group about it should be enough.
cootool.PBase: How do we decide together? Do you have any methodology to follow in order to take collective decisions?
cootool.details: If you want, add some details:
cootool.PD: Be creative, brainstorm! If you can't find the right solution, remember creativity may solve your situation. Sometimes the group want to be perfect, just and do the most righteous thing, but the creative mind can find an incredible different solution. Try this approach at first. Is it useful?
cootool.PU: List or discuss what are your participants most important principles and filter the ones in common. For example, even two opponent soldiers in a war may have their family safety in common. Use your common principles to evaluate your decisions. Try this approach. Is it useful?
cootool.PF: Check that all the participants have some personal space, both physical one and space for personal action. If it is not so, the group may need to separate. Separation is not 'bad', sometimes is a good natural step. Try this approach. Is it useful?
cootool.PI: It is important that any information that is not shared or any point of view that is not expressed should come up and overall be accepted by the group, no matter how bad it is. When truths are difficult to say or hear, give as much precise information as possible to understand how that truth come up and the principles that made up the choice behind the truth itself. Try this approach. Is it useful?
cootool.PC: When taking decisions or discussing delicate topics, the participants need a good environment and the right level of respect or care about their basic and intellectual needs. Try this approach. Is it useful?
cootool.PT: Sometimes the group needs to wait and meanwhile find measurements tool to evaluate the situation giving it a little more time. Trust your previous decisions while you evaluate them. Try this approach. Is it useful?
cootool.PE: If the group doesn't know which solution to take or if there is a contrast between different approaches, it could be very useful to experiment the different solutions giving them turns. Sometimes contrasting ideas or people can be useful together, combining them, or finding specific roles for each one of them. For example, in a contrast between someone wanting more innovation and someone wanting more security, you may give them specific roles in the group for it to be innovative in a safe way.  Try this approach. Is it useful?
cootool.AFinalNote:
Again, how do we decide together? This is the fundamental question. If nothing worked so far, Cooperacy invites you to try our basic process:

IN SHORT - Find a beautiful place in which you feel good and list the informations and the different options you have, then underline the values they are based upon. Merge them or create new ones, in case vote for them. Finally, make turns to experiment them dando fiducia ad alcune di esse e valutandone i risultati: start from the most voted and compensate those who renounce to their solution. If you still struggle, separate the group, giving each part of it a proportional space.

1. Give a moment to everyone in order to be aware of their own state, be it the emotional one, the one related to health, hunger or other needs, or be it context related, like warmth, coldness, luminosity, beauty of the surroundings and everything you may want to consider.
2. List all the different positions in the group, and relative information, without blocking anybody to express theirs and eventually ask explanation for any unclear position
3. Check which are the similarities in the choices proposed and write close to each one of them what is the value and the purpose behind the proposal. Find out if the different proposals or purposes may become parallel areas or functions, roles or responsibilities for the people proposing them.
4. If the situation is still unclear and someone has strict positions against one or more of the choices proposed, be transparent and explain why, then try to creatiely merge the current ones, or forget them completely and invent new ones. Brainstorm solutions, giving long time to the creative process and forgetting what is right or wrong.
5. If a choice does not arise, make the participants give maximum one vote to any position they like, even all of them, without being influenced by peers. If you are alone or in two, give a value between 1 and 100 or proceed intiutively.
6. Never choose only the most voted solution, but making proportions according to the votes, dedicate parts of your efforts, resources and time to develop or to test all the choices, in case making turns for each one of them and compensating those people whose proposal is abandoned.
7. Evaluate the results and in case go back to 1. If nothing works, make a long pause, and in case find a way to separate the group with care and in a balanced way, subdividing proportionally the available space and resouces.
cootool.PFinal: Try this final approach. Is it useful?
cootool.explain: Please explain why so we can learn from your experience!
cootool.checkbox: By clicking the GO! button you declare you read and are aware of the Cooperacy
cootool.checkboxend: , and that you acknowledge that this is an experimental tool based on scientific research but that has no liability nor gives you any warranty about your personal choices and future action that you will bring forward after fulfilling this questionnaire and reading its result.

cootoolreport.stagnation: Your diversity is very low, you may risk involution or stagnation.
cootoolreport.conflict: Your understanding is very low, you may risk conflicts.
cootoolreport.conflictD: Your diversity is high while your uderstanding is not as much: you may risk conflicts.

addplace.insert: Insert a place name after choosing a country
